subject: Art
title: RGB Color Model
description: How screens create color by adding red, green, and blue light.

hook.text: Zoom into your screen with a magnifying glass. You'll see tiny red, green, and blue dots. Every color on every screen in the world is made from just these three lights.

buildup.text: RGB is additive color: red + green = yellow. Red + blue = magenta. Green + blue = cyan. All three at full intensity = white. All off = black. It's the opposite of paint mixing.

discovery.text: Each channel ranges from 0-255, giving 256 levels per channel. 256 √ó 256 √ó 256 = 16.7 million possible colors. RGB(255,0,0) is pure red. RGB(0,255,0) is pure green. RGB(128,128,128) is middle gray.

twist.text: RGB colors can be more vivid than anything achievable with paint. Screens emit light; paper reflects it. That's why a photo on screen often looks more vibrant than the same image printed.

climax.text: Digital artists think in RGB. Understanding that your vivid screen colors may not translate to print is essential ‚Äî and it's why print uses a different color model entirely.

punchline.text: Screens add light to make color. Paint subtracts light. Same color theory, different physics.
